learning_outcomes.description: Reason with the logical foundation of the relational data model and understand the fundamental principles of correct relational database design.
Express natural language queries using relational algebra and SQL.
Analyse the fundamental techniques and algorithms applied for sorting, tree manipulation, and hashing on structured data.
Reason with the logical foundation on how data is indexed and how a query is executed and optimised.
Design relational databases with considerations of data integrity and system performance.

assessments.task_description:
In this project, each student is required to select an application that would benefit from a database, and build a database application from start to finish with the skills learned from this course. In Part 1 of this project, a proposal outlining the project scope, ER diagram, schema, and associated information will be delivered.

Note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Based on the designs from Part 1, Part 2 of this project focuses on SQL-based code implementation of the designed database. SQL Queries that fulfill specific functionalities are also required to be implemented. In Part 2, a final report detailing the database implementation and SQL execution results is required.

Note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Quiz Set 1 (ER Diagram and Relational Model) 13/03/2026 3:00 pm

Quiz Set 2 (Functional Dependencies and Normalisation) 27/03/2026 3:00 pm

Quiz Set 3 (SQL Programming) 17/04/2026 3:00 pm

Quiz Set 4 (Asymptotic Analysis, Sorting, and Binary Search Trees) 8/05/2026 3:00 pm

Quiz Set 5 (Hashing, Indexing, Relational Algebra and Query Optimisation) 29/05/2026 3:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
You are required to complete five quiz sets that respectively focus on:

(1) ER Diagram and Relational Model;

(2) Functional Dependencies and Normalisation;

(3) SQL Programming;

(4) Asymptotic Analysis, Sorting, and Binary Search Trees;

(5) Hashing, Indexing, Relational Algebra and Query Optimisation.Â 

Only the best four (i.e., the four with highest marks) out of the five quiz sets will contribute to the mark for this assessment. Each of the four best-performing quiz set accounts for 5% of the marks, totalling 20%. The full description of the platform (RiPPLE) used for the assessment is available on the course's Blackboard site.

Note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission will be managed through RiPPLE, UQ's own interactive learning platform. Corresponding instructions and guidelines will be made available on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Exams are designed to test theoretical concepts and modelling techniques introduced in lectures and tutorials.

Note: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The course lectures will provide in-depth knowledge of various concepts and techniques in the design of Database Management Systems (DBMS). Lecture notes will be available for all the material covered in this course. A series of in-class questions related to the course content will be raised to provide opportunities for better student engagement with content and in-depth discussions.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures The course lectures will provide in-depth knowledge of various concepts and techniques in the design of Database Management Systems (DBMS). Lecture notes will be available for all the material covered in this course. A series of in-class questions related to the course content will be raised to provide opportunities for better student engagement with content and in-depth discussions.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(02 Mar - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Applied Class

Hands-on applied classes will provide an opportunity to further practice the concepts introduced in the lectures via examples, exercises and problem-solving. They will also allow students to become familiar with various methods in the implementation and optimization of database systems.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
